posts.name: Tetsuya Cox
posts.cooked: I’m connected to the Rio via USB, and nothing else is plugged in. When I try to image the Rio, an error message appears. I’ve tried restarting both the robot and the computer, and also ran the rio imaging tool as an administrator. The image file is named 'image' with dimensions 1274×753 pixels and a size of 127 KB.
Did you try putting the roboRIO in safe mode and/or updating the firmware of the RIO, or both at the same time?

posts.name: Tetsuya Cox
posts.cooked: I did try putting it in safe mode, but the imaging tool cannot find the rios anymore.
Hold down the RESET button while the STATUS LED turns on, then release after holding for 1-2 minutes. Interestingly, a similar issue caused the device to enter safe mode and become discoverable.

posts.name: Tetsuya Cox
posts.cooked: I tried that, and the imager could see it, but then this happened. Image with dimensions 1265×760 pixels, file size 125 KB.

Ensure your RoboRIO's connectivity by verifying your cable setup. Similar issues may arise due to corrupt firmware caused by a faulty cable connection, as indicated by an error message prompting you to use an Ethernet cable. To facilitate image transfer via Ethernet, set the IP address of the network adapter to 172.22.11.2.

For further assistance, open Run (Windows + R) and input `ncpa.cpl` to configure your system. On your network adapters, deactivate WiFi and Bluetooth, retaining only the Ethernet connection. Access the Ethernet cable configuration by right-clicking the available adapter and selecting Properties. Adjust the IP settings as directed, ensuring the adapter uses the correct IP for USB-like connections.

After updating the firmware and installing FIRST Robotics Competition software, remember to restore the adapter's auto-IP feature. If successful, consider upgrading your tether to a USB-A to USB-B cable for future connectivity needs.

posts.name: Noah Loyacano
posts.cooked: Are you using a Roboio 1.0 or 2.0? I'm just checking because the imaging tool can't process images on the 2.0 model.

posts.name: Tetsuya Cox
posts.cooked: I will try that as soon as I can. Thank you

posts.name: Ryan Fortner
posts.cooked: Hi! My team was having similar issues with imaging a RIO earlier in the year. We ended up having to flash a recovery image, which can be found here along with instructions for both rio 1 and 2. https://knowledge.ni.com/KnowledgeArticleDetails?id=kA03q000000kOHkCAM&l=en-US. Hope this helps!
